ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class helped me understand more of the nuances behind research methods of political science. Specifically the theory behind mixed methods and incorporating quantitative and qualitative methodology in research.
I learned how to create my own research design integrating both qualitative and quantitative methods.
Insight into the mixed methods research process

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Some of the lessons felt a little repetitive and I could have used more background on a few methods before the ethical discussions.
The course was composed of a majority PhD students which made it hard to follow as an undergraduate student. I was definitely challenged.

Strengths: discussions, feedback, and office hours are all very in-depth and helpful. Morgan and Professor Nugent are both amazing--two of the best I have had at Yale!! It might have been helpful to spend a little more time on how to apply mixed methods techniques, as opposed to focusing on the theory, but there was so much critical information packed into one term.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Great way to start thinking about independent research/ if you are a junior, you can plan out your thesis in PoliSci!
Definitely, if you're at all interested in the subject matter.
